statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Cincinnati 70, Howard 39
article.story: CINCINNATI (AP) -- Newcomer John Williamson scored 18 points on Friday night, leading Cincinnati to a 70-39 victory over poor-shooting Howard in Mick Cronin's debut at the Bearcats' coach. Cincinnati (1-0) never trailed in the opening game of the Jim Thorpe Classic, a three-day exempted tournament. Tennessee-Martin and High Point also are participating in the round-robin event on Cincinnati's home court. Williamson, a 6-foot-6 forward who transferred from Cincinnati State, scored nine of the Bearcats' first 11 points in the second half, starting a surge that pushed the lead to 31 points. Darryl Hudson scored 18 points for Howard (0-1), which returns four starters from a team that went 7-22 last season. Hudson was its leading scorer and rebounder last season. The Bison shot only 21 percent from the field and went 2-of-12 on 3-point tries. Cronin, who grew up in Cincinnati and was one of Bob Huggins' assistants for five years, was hired to help the Bearcats get beyond one of their most tumultuous years. Huggins was forced out shortly before the start of the 2005-06 season, a move that divided the city and left the team in turmoil. Assistant Andy Kennedy took over on an interim basis and, with the help of five seniors, guided the Bearcats to an NIT appearance. Although fans clamored for Kennedy to get the job, the university turned to Cronin, whose local ties struck the right chord with fans. His first task was cobbling together a team on short notice. Only one starter returns from last season's team -- forward Cedric McGowan, who averaged 8.5 points. Reserve forward Ronald Allen is the only other player with Division I experience. Cronin has to rely on a roster of junior college transfers that features only 10 players on scholarship. McGowan and Allen had 10 points apiece. Cronin was often perturbed by his team's ragged play on Friday, at one point angrily flinging a white towel behind the bench. The Bearcats had trouble holding onto the ball and making open shots. Against Howard, the lack of experience and depth didn't matter much. Howard missed its first eight shots and was only 4-of-28 from the field while falling behind 35-17 in the first half.
